dialogues.text: Out the window the dead body of a man suddenly slams into FRAME. He dangles grotesquely, held up by his coat caught on a protruding bolt. George gasps. The train WHISTLE SCREAMS. We see clearly the face of the dead man -- an older gentl with a white moustache and goatee. He has been beaten and shot in the head and the blood trickles down the side of face. dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There was a man out the window. He'd been shot in the head.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: What? ,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (very excitedly) Hilly, I'm not joking. A dead man fell off the roof. His coat was caught. I saw it. What should I do? I've got to report it. Maybe they can stop the train.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey! Lighten up! She gets off the bed and takes hold of him.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: C'mon now. Sit down. You need a little more champagne.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding, Hilly. I saw it.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Here. George sits and Hilly pours him some champagne. George drinks it down in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wow! I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But I saw it, really I did.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Of course. I'm sure you saw something. An old newspaper. A kid's kite. Look, like thatt She points out the window. The train WHISTLE SCREAMS agai and we see a white signal box whip by. George's convictio is momentarily shaken.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: It could have been anything out there.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. It was a body -- a dead man. His eyes were so clear.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: More clear than your head. George, 465 you imagined it. Cont..,  465 REVISED - “THE SILVER STREAK" ~ 4/3776 18 23 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm positive I didn't,

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: All right then, call the conductor and tell him your story.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He'll think I've been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Where would he get that idea?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But, Hilly, it was so...vivid.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Come here. Hilly fluffs up his pillow and urges him to put his legs George rubs his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wow, I feel kind of dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Lie down. George falls back on the bed with a sigh. Hilly picks up cassette recorder which stopped playing when George knock it over and looks around for a place where it will be saf She starts the music ("Hilly's Theme") and puts it on a h overhanging rack near the window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Boy, if that's what the Df's are like, I'm giving up the bottle for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mind plays funny tricks all the time. You know that. Just relax and forget it. Hilly turns off the lights and lies alongside George. He looks at her for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That sure is a pretty song.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, it is, He kisses her gently on the lips and then looks at her wi a@ great deal of tenderness. Cont.  465 19 23 Cont.2

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You are very beautiful, Hilly. Hilly despite her sophistication 1s not used to this tend ness. Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I like you, too. He moves forward again and they kiss long and passionatel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We DISSOLVE from the rattling night wheels of the Silver Streak to a HIGH ANGLE SHOT of the desert sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, looking bright-~eyed and happy, exits from the ba room where he has washed and shaved. He puts on a clean s and hums to himself "Hilly's Theme," as he buttons it up. Hilly is lying in bed, deep in a relaxed and contented sl George looks at his watch and picks up a train schedule t see when they will arrive at the next station. He puts th schedule in his back pocket, sees the empty champagne bot and picks it up with fond remembrance of the lovemaking t night before. Then he remembers his vision of the dead ma and his expression changes. He steps to the window and ig ing the desert in bloom stretches his neck to try to see roof. Unsatisfied, he steps to the next window, folds up bed. to make the couch and tries again to see the outside of the train. He finally gives this up, looks at the bost and drops it into the wastebasket. He goes over to Hilly smiles down at her. : Leaning forward to gently touch her hair, he knocks the : Rembrandt book off the chair. He picks it up and notices envelope stuffed with papers sticking out from under the jacket cover. He pats the envelope back in place and is a to put it down when he turns it over to look at the autho picture on the back. He gasps with surprise for the pictu of the grey-haired old man with the white goatee is the s man he saw hanging dead outside the window. The train lur and George staggers. Turning quickly to Hilly, he shakes awake, .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly! Hilly! Wake up. Look at this. Hilly stirs and sits up, still half-asileep.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: What, what?... She sees George and gives him a sexy, kittenish smile.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, George. Cont.  465 20 25 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, the dead man I saw out the window last night -- this is him! Hilly seems interested for a moment till George shows her pack picture on the book. She looks at it with some confusion.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George, that's my boss. That's Professor Schreiner.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George, what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's after eight.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Eight! Wake me again after ten. She closes her eyes and lies down, cuddling up to a pillo

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, this man has been murdered.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well... (she thinks sleepily) Why don't you go and discuss it with him and then come back here later and discuss it with me. His room is just past the diner. Room D.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (exasperatedly) Hilly...

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Good night, George. You're a wonderful gardener. George walks away from the bed and paces to his side of t room. He looks at the book again and throws it into his o briefcase with such force that the lid closes over it. He not sure what to do. He looks at the window and finally m up his mind. Taking his coat from his closet, he puts it: and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George closes the door behind him and begins walking towa the rear of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diner is not too crowded as George enters. The Mexica Mama-san is having breakfast with the Blue-Haired Cont  465 21 . 27 Cont. Lady. When she sees George she points him out to her comp ion as the mad rapist of the night before. ‘The Blue-Hair Lady looks around and scowls at George as he passes. Swee is seated at the end of the car and seems very. eager to question George.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Hey, George, you devil. Join me for coffee? .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think Iwill. I just have to check on something. I'11 be right back. Sweet nods and George keeps on walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile Hilly is still sleeping. We PAN from her to the door and it opens slowly. A man steps in and closes the door behind him. : As we PAN UP we see he has a gun in a shoulder holster. H steps forward and we see his face -~ an ugly, prizefighte mug with a sneering mouthful of solid gold teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks down the corridor looking at the letters on doors. He finds "D" and stops. He starts to knock. Then hesitates, debating in his mind if he is not being a fool about the whole thing. Suddenly from inside the room’ he hears scuffling and an angry voice swearing. George liste and then knocks on the door. The scuffling stops. The doo is slowly opened by a bespectacled little man who stands the doorway sucking on a white, plastic "Quit Smoking" cigarette. This is MR. WHINEY.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Professor Schreiner.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My name's George Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: You a friend of the professor?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, not exactly. I'm a friend of his secretary, and-we were worried about him. Cont.  465 22 29 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? What are you worried about?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Can't I talk to the professor. Where is he...? George pushes against the door to see inside the room. He can't see anyone but notices the luggage has been thoroug searched and much of the room is in a mess.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there? Whiney pushes George back. Hey, I think you're sticking your nose in where it don't belong. You and that broad are: gonna get yourself in trouble. ‘Fact, she's already in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know who you are but...

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Hey, Reace! Get rid of this bum! George is suddenly grabbed from behind and pitched down the corridor. -Whiney slams the door shut. George turns t look at his unseen assailant. It is the ugly pug with the gold teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! You can't do that to me, Gold Teeth strides toward George, shoves him up against t side of the train and twists his arm up behind his back. George yells in pain and struggles manfully.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, you big ox, what the hell do you think you're doing. Hold it. Let me go. Gold Teeth doesn't say a word. He just begins walking to end of the corridor forcing George to walk in front of hi  465 23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth bangs the door at the end of the corridor and opens. He throws George into the corner and turns to the side door of the train. George stands, rubbing his arn. He is really mad.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you're in trouble. I mean it. Big trouble. I'm reporting you... Gold Teeth flings open the side door of the train and tur to face George. George looks at the door and his attitude changes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: All right...okay...enough is enough...Let's forget the whole thing... Gold Teeth is unmoved. He lunges for George, grabs him by the collar and the seat of the pants and with no effort a all pitches him right off the train.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE DESERT
dialogues.text: George flies through the air and lands on the sandy bank an empty riverbed. He rolls and tumbles and finally comes a stop in a cloud of dust. The train races past. George can't believe what happened. He sits up, shakes his head and looks as the last carriage of the Silver Streak rattl by.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What the -- | He stands up and feels himself. He is not hurt. He dusts himself off and notices that the sleeve on his jacket has been ripped. He fingers it lovingly. Then he begins to ge the full realization of what has happened. He runs up to railway tracks and squints at the train racing off in the distance. He looks behind him and out across the flat des on either side. There is no sign of life or civilization anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch! He kicks the gravel on the railway ties and begins walkin down the tracks after the Silver Streak.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 322
dialogues.text: In the vast stretches of the lonely desert, we see George a solitary speck in the wilderness, following the railway line beneath the sweltering sun.  465 a4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, his coat over his shoulder, is walking along the of the railroad tracks, mittering to himself about his fa The beauty of the green sagebrush and the yellow wildflcw in bloom is completely escaping him. A few cows are grazi in the distance but George doesn't care. He stops at the sight of a cattle skull at his feet, half buried in the s

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (bitterly) Terrific! . He shakes his head, grits his teeth and continues walking kicking the occasional cactus. EXT. THE DESERT - DAY 34° George has been walking for almost two hours. The terrain has changed -- red rock mesas and mountains on the horizo George climbs up on one of the smaller mesas » and, shiel his eyes from the sun, peers off in all directions. Sudde he sees something. He looks again. Off across the flat plain is a farmhouse and a windmill, a distant vision tha sits incongruously on the desert floor like @ children's model left in a sandbox. George squeals with delight, jum down, and begins running toward it as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: DAY , 35
dialogues.text: The farmhouse is a startling sight, a clapboard oasis sticking up in the middle of nowhere. A dusty road leads what is essentially two buildings -- the main house built the Mexican adobe style and a large barn, somewhat red, t looks like it was transported from South Carolina. Betwee them is a yard encircled by a corral, a cow shed, a chick coop, and an outhouse made from a 1930's silver camper- trailer, George runs INTO FRAME and down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George arrives at the farmyard and stops to catch his bre He looks around at the pigsty, the turkeys in the chicken coop, and the lazy-eyed dog who glances up disinterestedl from his kennel. He walks over to a 1950 Chevy parked by the porch and is about to knock on the front door when he hears the SOUND of "spit-spit-spit" coming from the cow s Ducking under the clothesline, he goes to the cow shed do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RITA BABTREE, a large, self-reliant Southern lady in her sixties is seated on a stool milking one of the cows, She hears George enter but doesn't stop or turn around.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: If that's you, Pepe, you are in one heap of trouble. Cont.  25 37 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, it's not. Rita looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Where's Pepe? GEORGE . I don't know. My name's Caldwell. George Caldwell. ~ Rita turns back to milking with a vengeance.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Goddammit! I knew itl He's gone off again with that no-account Manuel. Those two get together, smoke a little weed, and the next thing they're out buzzing turkeys in the pickup. I should have fired him thirty years ago. George walks around so he is facing her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, do you have a telephone?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: A telephone? You ain't from around here, are you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. I'm lost...I, ah...Well, I was thrown off the Silver Streak.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thrown off? That a fact? I ain't heard of folks riding hobo on the Streak since the Depression.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I-wasn't riding hobo. I had a ticket. Some other passengers threw me off. It was a fight. That's why I want to telephone the police and have those guys arrested.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Thrown off, huh? Tell me, is there @ woman in all this?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, there is a girl...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (chuckling) I knew it! Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But it's not what you're thinking. She could be in a great deal of danger herself. I've got to get to the police as soon... Rita finishes milking and stands up. She pours the milk f the bucket into the large can in the old freezer.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sounds like you're in a hurry?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's fine, ‘cause I'm running late myself. I'11 tell you what, Steve...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: George.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: George Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Rita Babtree. If you finish milking Harriet over there I'll go change and you can ride into town with me. The Sheriff's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Great! What do I have to do?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Take this bucket and milk her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think I've ever milked a cow before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the gas, Steve. You're a grown man. I'm sure you've had some similar experience.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Look, sit down, take a tit in each hand and let nature take its course. These cows are so full it's like tapping a trip valve on Niagara Falls. 46 3 Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 37 Cont.2 She hands George the stool and bucket and slams the freez door.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Put the milk in here and I'll meet you outside in ten minutes. Rita exits. George puts down the stool and sits beside Harriet. He places the bucket beneath her udder and nervously rubs his hands together. Then, gingerly, he reaches out and takes a teat in each fist. He begins to squeeze and pull. Nothing happens. He tries again. Nothing. Harriet stops her chewing and looks around. Geor smiles at her and tries harder. This time one squirt spit into the empty bucket. George beams. He tries again. Another short squirt. Harriet grunts disgustedly. George stops and looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm a slow starter...But what happened to Niagara Falls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita exits from the house wearing jodhpurs and a leather jacket and carrying five large parcels tied up with strin She steps off the porch and is surprised to see George sitting in the front seat of the Chevy reading something while he waits for her.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Steve?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm looking at the schedule for the Silver Streak.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No, no. I mean what are you sitting in...? We ain't going in that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita flings open the barn doors and George stands staring an old-fashioned two-seater biplane parked in the center the hangar-like barn.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Put these packages in the backseat with you and I'll get the wheel blocks. I only hope Pepe has filled it with enough gas.  4€5

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: INT. THE BARN - DAY 4o Rita walks off to the end of the barn and pushes open the two large doors. George eyes the plane like it was some Smithsonian antique.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are we going to fly in this?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's the matter? -- you afraid of flying?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no. People keep asking that. I am not afraid of flying!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Great! ‘Cause it ain't no fun soaring with a turkey. Like Jack used to say -- you take some greenhorn up, do a few loop-the- loops and suddenly you got yourself an outhouse in the sky. (chuckling ) Oh, that Jack! He was something special. Rita puts on her flying goggles and her white scarf and climbs into the cockpit. George finishes stacking the packages in the backseat, and climbs in behind her. He takes

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: C'mon, Steve. Hop to it! f want to be in Stavely by two o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Two o'clock! stammering ) It's now only eleven-thirty...how far?..-how long? (finally) Where is Stavely?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Sixty miles the other side of Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. out the train schedule and looks at it eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak stops there at two twenty-seven! If we get there by two we can-have the sheriff meet the train when it arrives.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Ready? Watch those parcels. Cont.  465 29 40 Cont. Rita starts the engine. George settles in the seat and straps himself in still smiling at the good news.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is fabulous! Rita moves out. EXT, THE FIELD - DAY an The plane is racing along the bumpy runway field, picking speed with every bounce. Rita has her goggles down and gu the engine while her white scarf flaps in the wind, Georg is white-faced and terrified -- a direct contrast from tn shot before. He looks ahead at the approaching windmill a tugs nervously at his seat belt and shoulder strap as the plane jumps up and down like a bilious bird. Finally with mighty effort Rita pulls back on the stick and the plane surges into flight. Up, up it goes and to George's wide-e horror it misses by inches the top arm of the windmill. R is too happy to even notice. She shouts back.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: They talk of the joy of sex, Steve, but it don't last like the fun of flying!

dialogues.speaker: DAY 42
dialogues.text: A medley of SHOTS showing Rita and George flying over the changing Arizona landscape and into New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE SKY
dialogues.text: George looks down and sees the Silver Streak snaking its along the tracks below them. He points it out to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's the Silver Streak. EXT, THE SKY - DAY 4d They are well ahead of the train now and are flying over pastures. George glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think we're going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Look at those sheep. Don't they make a lovely sight. Oh, I'm just itching to buzz them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Buzz them? What's that? Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 44 cont.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You never buzzed sheep before?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (chuckling to herself) Oh, I really shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe just one run. Hold on, Steve. We're going in. Like a sheep dog of the skies Rita zooms down toward the sheep, soars over their backs as they scatter in bleating panic. She laughs with sinful glee.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Look at those dumb little critters run!...O0h, my God, I'm a wicked old lady -- but ain't that a hoot! She chuckles some more and stares down at the flock. Obviously she is thinking of doing it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old yellow VW convertible speeds down a dusty road fro the little desert airport in the b.g. Rita is driving and George is sitting beside her looking very worried. He glances at his watch, shakes his head and shouts at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think we're going to make it. It's after two o'clock already.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We'll make it. Don't worry...But I guess we shouldn't have stopped to buzz those sheep. They speed on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stavely.is a small western town situated at the foot of t Rocky Mountains and built on either side of a main street with the train station at one end. Rita and George come speeding into town and pull up in front of the Sheriff's office. An old PROSPECTOR is sitting in a chair by the do Cont.  465 31 46 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: The sheriff in, Burt?

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hello, Rita. No, he's over at Clancey's Dairy. He'll be back in about... George interrupts with a howl as he sees that the Silver Streak is standing at the station ready to depart.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, there's the Silver Streak!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You want to go get the sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no! I've got to run, Thanks, Rita. Bye. He runs off toward the end of town, Rita yells after hin:

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: So long, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Crazy kidl

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And this time try to stay on. gur 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George catches up to the moving train and runs alongside. the last car some drunken CONVENTIONEERS see him and open door, yelling encouragement to him.

dialogues.speaker: . FIRST CONVENTIONEER
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. You can make it.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CONVENTIONEER
dialogues.text: That's iti That's it! Grab on. George hops onto the train and the Conventioneers congrat him with gusto, slapping him on the back and offering to join them in a drink. They hustle him away. INT. THE COACH LOUNGE - DAY 4g The lounge is crowded with Conventioneers in the middle o their two-dey party. George enters with his three new friends who. eagerly show him the cardboard cut-out of "Mary-Lou." He sees Plain Jane, who is having a wonderful time boozing it up. She stops George as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: PLAIN JANE
dialogues.text: Don't you just love train travel. Cont.  465 32 49 Cont. George smiles and ad-libbing his apologies leaves the par

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-heartedly fixing up his disheveled appearance George walks through the rest of the second-class section. Most the passengers are poor, old, kids or hippies happily blo away on pot. An AMISH COUPLE read their prayer books whil two HONEYMOONING REPUBLICANS take 8mm movies from the tra window, George passes them all without turning his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is beginning its climb up the spectacul scenery of the Rocky Mountains.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE FIRST-CLASS DINER
dialogues.text: George is walking toward the dining car when he stops at door and steps back so he won't be noticed. He looks agai into the dining car and we see what he sees -- Hilly with her back towards us is finishing a late lunch with Roger Devereau, the suave, continental gentleman we glimp earlier. George is surprised to see her with Devereau and about to approach her when he notices that Devereau, in conversation, pats her hand somewhat intimately...George stops short. He is confused and sits quietly down at the nearest table to watch her. Sweet is at the table, readin newspaper. He puts it down and looks at George.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I asked you to join me for breakfast. This is lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry. I lost track of the time.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What were you doing back there? Getting yourself a little ass?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Actually I was squeezing some tits.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: You sexy devil! And you look like you worked up a sweat, too, ya horny bastard. George is not listening. He is watching Hilly. Sweet look around and turns back to George.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Well, what do you expect? She's a hot little number and he's heavy competition.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know him? Cont.  465 33 52 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Doesn't everybody? Name is Roger Devereau, Chicago's own jet-setter. The Tribune is always talking about him. He's the big cheese on the board of the Art Institute. Like I say, heavy competition. Hilly and Devereau get up from the table. George ducks hi head so he won't be seen.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: You going to take him on? Hilly and Devereau exit out the far door. George stands u to follow.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Let me know how it turns out. George walks down the aisle and out the dining car door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking great care not to be seen, George follows Devereau Hilly down the. center aisle with roomettes on either sid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of his car George waits and peers around the corner. Hilly has stopped by her door. She talks for « second to Devereau and then steps inside. Devereau walks forward to the baggage car. As soon as he disappears, Geo goes to his compartment and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing we notice is the partition between his an Hilly's rooms has been put back up and the connecting doo closed. George listens for a moment at the door and then opens it slowly. Hilly is kneeling on the couch sadly leoking out the window. She sees George and couldn't be more surprised. :

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George! George steps into her room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, are you all right? Cont.  465 34 A=-55 Cont. Hilly springs off the couch and into his arms. She holcs him desperately. George is more confused than ever.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, what's the matter? Hilly suddenly breaks away from hin, totally changing her emotion from one of need to one of nonchalance.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Tne matter? Who left who? The last I heard you were going to visit the professor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The professor is dead. Murdered. I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, George...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, listen to me. I went to his room this morning and he wasn't there. Instead two thugs were going through his things. They pushed me out, twisted my arm and threw me off the train.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Threw you off!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The point is they were looking for something. They've killed the professor to get it and now I'm sure they'll be after you. We've got to get off at the next stop and contact the police.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, George. You've got it all mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, this is serious. (grabs hold of her) I'm worried about you...I'm... He looks in her eyes. She looks in his. There is obvicusl a strong emotional bond between them. Suddenly the door opens and Devereau walks in. Hilly quickly steps away fro George. She smiles at Devereau who smiles back but we see Cont.  465 35 A-55 Cont.1 his cold eyes that the intimacy of the scene he just interrupted is extremely disturbing to him.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Hello, Roger. I'd like you to meet a friend of mine, George Caldwell.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George was just telling me how he had been thrown off the train.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: You! You're the one. Oh, I am happy to see you. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (confused) - Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Well, that's good news, You know, as soon as I was told I contacted. the police in Albuquerque. [I told them to spare no expense in making sure you were safe. Reace, himself, got off the train to find you. He's like a child. He wanted to say he was sorry. Tell me, how did you manage to get back on?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait, wait a minute. Who's Reace?

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Reace? Why, he's the man who threw you off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: You must remember him. A large man with not very attractive dental work.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I remember, but what's he got to do with you? cont.  36 A-55 Cont,.2

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: He works for me, He's my chauffeur.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Butes.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: He's not very bright, of course, put very loyal. Naturally I take full responsibility for his actions and I am more than willing to pay for any damages. I'm just so relieved to see that you are not hurt. :

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Who was that:other guy? He work for you, too? .

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Yes. Oh, you haven't heard the story? You see, early this morning I was having breakfast with Professor Schreiner. He wanted to show me some important papers connected with his book but to his horror he couldn't find them. We searched his compartment -- twice. We sent Reace in here to get Hilly and finally we found them in his trunk in the baggage car. It was a terrible upset but then if you've met the professor, you know he can be very absent-minded.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George thinks the professor has been murdered.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Murdered?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's right. Last night.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: How extraordinary! What makes you think that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I saw his body fall from the roof right by that window. He was shot in the head.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: You were in this room? Devereau glances at Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was lying right there. It was so clear -- the blood, his face. I'll 465 never forget it.  37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and PROFESSOR SCHREINER walks in. George i thunderstruck. and stares open-mouthedly at the trim, hea elderly gentleman with the white moustache and goatee -- very same person he had seen fall dead the night before. Professor has just stepped in to talk to Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Hilly, youtll have to go to my compartment and straighten it out. That man, Whiney; doesn't know what "he's doing. Ah, Devereau.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Professor Schreiner, I'd like you to meet Mr. Caldwell. Mr. Caldwell, Professor Schreiner. .

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Hello. What did you do to your jacket?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, eh...I..-

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Mr. Caldwell was the man Reace inadvertently threw off the train.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. That stupid mant I do hope you weren't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: I suppose I'm to blame for this morning's fracas. After all, none of this would have happened if I hadn't misplaced the Rembrandt letters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. I'm so glad that you are all right and managed to get back on the train. The door opens and Mr. Whiney, the bespectacled little gu with the plastic cigarette enters to ask the Professor a question.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY'
dialogues.text: Professor, I've put back as much... (sees George) 465 Hey! How'd you get here? Cont.  38 56 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Mr, Caldwell, allow me to introduce my associate, Mr. Whiney. I'm sure if there is an apology owed he'll be happy to make it. It's too bad Reace isn't here to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Reace, that moron! It was all his fault. I was looking for the papers. (to George} I never touched you, did I?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: See.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Well, it's all been very hectic for me, I'm going to have a scotch and lie down.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Why don't you use my compartment?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Thank you, I think I will. (gesturing at Whiney) Hilly, give him a hand with that mess. (e George) Mr. Caldwell, it was nice meeting you. I hope for both of us the rest of the trip will be a little less exhilarating. The Professor leaves. George looks at Devereau, Whiney and Hilly -- especially Hilly -- and has never felt so utterly embarrassed. He attempts to smile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I think I've really made a fool of myself this morning.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I'm sticking my nose into a lot of stuff that's none of my business and getting a lot of crazy ideas. (to Hilly) You were right. I was seeing a lot of nonsense last night. Too much champagne. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: ‘ . 56 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Oh, George. - (sympathetically) Here, let me fix your jacket. . GEORGE . No, that's okay. I've got another. He goes to the door and steps into his room. It is obviou that he is upset and jealous over Devereau's interest in Hilly but he feels that he has made such an ass out of hi self in front of both of them that he Just wants to get a

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, we get into Chicago tomorrow and I ‘did have some work to do on, this trip, so I'll just say good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU . L
dialogues.text: Perhaps you can join us for dinner, Mr. Caldwell?

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Yes, do. .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. No. I think I will probably have my meals in here. As he closés the door he gives one parting shot for Hilly benefit. _ . .

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hmmm.. The latch is broken. I'1l gét the. porter to have that fixed ‘right. away. - & He shuts the door. Mr. Whiney sits down on the couch and. pégins to snicker. But Devereau's expression changes from serenely confident to deeply troubled. He turns to Hilly looks at him in her insouciant way. Suddenly and viciousl he SLAPS her across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver Streak is making a steady climb up the mountai grade, passing beside the many treacherous gorges that fa off to the side. :

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE LOUNGE CAR
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon. George is shaved and changed and seated at a lounge car table beside one of the picture windows. He has before him a bucket of ice, some soda and cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 58 Cont. six miniature bottles of scotch, plus two empty ones line up in a row. He takes a sip of scotch from his glass, see Sweet enter and waves him over.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, Sweet! Come join me. (to bartender) Bring the man some ice. Sweet comés over and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: What are you -- a miniature alcoholic?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We are soon approaching the Rayner Tunnel, the highest point on the line. when we reach it, I intend to be even higher.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Be careful you don't fall off. The bartender brings over Sweet's glass and George pours the contents of one of the bottles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, no! I've left the train once this trip. And once is definitely ‘enough.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: What do you mean? George settles back to tell his story.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Last night in the blonde's compartment, I had a bizarre hallucination. I thought I saw her boss hanging dead outside the window.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: You mean Professor Schreiner?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The same. Shot through the head. I knew I'd been drinking but this morning when I go looking for the Professor I meet this short little weasel of a guy in his room. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: , ‘ 58 cont.1

dialogues.speaker: SWEET '
dialogues.text: Edgar whiney.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I know. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, suddenly this moving mountain with a gold mine stuck in his gums, pitches me off the train. and if that isn't...

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: (Anterrupting) So you never saw the Professor?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nope. ‘I met him for the first time this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In Hilly's compartment. She introduced us. You see, the whole thing was just one big disunderstanding. Apparently...

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: What did he look like?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Like his picture. Why these questions?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: What did he say to you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing much. He was feeling tired and went to have a scotch.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: A scotch?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's lying down in Devereau's compartment. You want some more ice? cont. 465

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 Cont.2 Sweet, who has been earnestly mulling over this informati snaps to attention.

dialogues.speaker: . SWEET
dialogues.text: of course! He looks at George with a new gleam in his eye -- almost if he were another character -- and stops him from openin another of the little scotch bottles.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: That's enough of that! You. sober up. We've got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ir beg your pardon!

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Listen, that was no hallucination you had. The Professor has been murdered. The guy you saw this afternoon ‘is a fake. whe. GEORGE t? : Cont. 465  465

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I spoke with the real Professor 43 58 cont.3 last night. He didn't want anything to do with Devereau. Besides, he was a health nut. He didn't touch alcohol. ,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Aww, just because you're in the health food business... Sweet reaches for his wallet and flashes a badge at Georg

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: My name is Stephens...I'm a Federal agent. (puts it away) We've been working on this case for two years. George has sobered up fast -- but is still

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't understand. Why were you tailing the Professor?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I wasn't. I'm tailing Devereau. Let's go. He stands up. George picks up the bottles the bar while his mind races.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Devereau? Well, what about Hilly?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: confused. and puts them on Don't worry about it. I don't think they'1l kill her before we get to Chicago. I don't think they'11 even kill you -- till then. George gulps, smiles vaguely at the Bartend Sweet, walking briskly out of the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: er and follows 59 Sweet is making his way down the corridor with an alertne and @ purpose that we have not seen before. Fat Men steps from his room. Sweet keeps w

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Beat it, fatso. One of the falking. The Fat Man is shocked but scurries back to his room to l Sweet pass. George following behind is very impressed.  REVISED - "THE SILVER STREAK" - 4/9/76 ak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet opens the baggage car door, and the two men step in and look around. It is basically a boxcar with some shelv built on the sides and some racks from which bicycles han upside down. Half of the storage is cardboard cartons, su cases, and large travelling trunks. The other is the equi ment for the "Sea and Sun" convention -- collapsible disp booths, signs, cardboard cutouts of "Mary-Lou," and vario items of sports equipment -- canoes, paddles, inflatable rafts, and underwater spear fishing outfits.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Devereau's men must have brought the Professor here last night some time after nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How do you figure that?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Because [ left him at nine, and because this is the one place where there is easy access to the roof. (pointing) Somehow he escaped, made it up that ladder and down the train before they shot hin. He walks out the far door and onto the outside platform. George follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no covering over this platform, and Sweet begins climbing up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're not going up there, are you?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Rayner Tunnel is up ahead. Keep a lookout for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: All right, I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Just watch out for low hanging signal arms. He finishes climbing and steps up onto the roof. George swallows hard and begins climbing up after him. 465  465

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet is walking down the center of the car. He looks bac at George who has reached the top of the ladder, but who not yet willing to stand up on the roof. Sweet smiles and waves okay. He begins walking down the roof of the train, nimbly jumping over between the cars. George watches him with a great deal of trepidation. He looks down to his side and sees a great Rocky Mountain gorge several hundre feet below. It's obvious that there ain't anything that would get him to go walking on the top of this train. swe bends down and picks up something. He looks around, then makes his way back to the ladder. George climbs down and waits for Sweet. They both go into the baggage car and close the door, .

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: What did you find? Sweet hands George a piece of material that he found on t train roof.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: It was hooked on a protruding bolt. George fingers the piece of material. It is obvious that it came from the dead Professor's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then I was right. I did see him.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I'll bet Devereau has already had the body picked up and placed in cold storage somewhere. Too bad. He was a sweet old guy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But why would Devereau want to kill the Professor? Sweet takes the material and places it carefully in his wallet. As he opens his jacket, George notices he is carrying a guh. Sweet begins snooping around the baggage car, picking up various pieces of sports equipment. He Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: "REVISED
dialogues.text: 63 Cont. seems to be looking for something or maybe just trying to figure out how the Professor escaped. He opens and closes the large side door.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Devereau was going to be embarrassed by the findings in his book. Two of the Institute's Rembrandts -- both bought and authenticated by Devereau -- were going to be proved as forgeries, and the Professor had the proof in his posseasion. I asked him what this proof was. He smiled cagliy and told me I'd have to wait for his lecture.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Devereau wasn't going to wait. SWEET . No. Look, here's Devereau's safe... Sweet kneels down to examine it, but continues with his story.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: The idea I think was to kidnap then kill the Professor, substitute a phony look-alike who would botch the lecture and discredit the book. Sweet stands up apparently satisfied with his inspection the safe.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: We've got to find that proof.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But they have it. That's what Whiney and everyone was looking for this morning -- the Rembrandt letters! They said they found them in the Professor's trunk.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: They were lying. That was the first place they looked before they began turning his room upside down. No, the Professor hid them somewhere -- some place simple...just as a precaution when he learned that Devereau was on the train. He had no time to -- cont.  REVISED ~ "THE SILVER STREAK" - 4/9/76 ur 63 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My God! I know where they arel Sweet reacts. George flings open the baggage car door and strides down the corridor. Sweet follows, but has to walk quickly to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Fat Man is stepping out of the public toilet a the end of the car. George is rushing toward him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Beat it, fatso. He is completely startled and quickly steps back into the toilet. George doesn't stop. He steps around the corridor and opens his compartment door.

dialogues.speaker: INT, GEORGE'S COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: George walks in followed by Sweet who closes the door. Ge quickly takes his briefcase from the chair, opens it, and with a sigh of relief takes out the Professor's book on Rembrandt. He throws down the briefcase and opens the jac cover of the book, Very carefully he removes the envelope and takes out the contents -- three pieces of old, but st parchment paper covered in neat scribblings of black ink. George @lances over them and offers them to Sweet with a smile,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The Rembrandt letters. Sweet takes them and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Holy Toledo, I think you've found them. (looking through them) The genuine article, penned by the old boy himself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (reading the signature) Rembrandt van Rijn.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: My guess is that there is some fact, some date in all of this that proves the charges the Professor makes in his book. And that means bye-bye, Devereau. (folding them up) Press the button for the porter. I want to get the conductor in here and radio a message to the next town. George presses the signal for the porter. He sits down an puts the letters back in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's hard to believe that a man was killed over these. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 65 Cont. ~

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: They're only the tip of the iceberg. That plane crash in Cologne was one of Devereau's specials -- a hundred people killed to cover up his involvement in the Metropolitan Gallery scandal.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why wasn't he caught?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: No proof. But with those letters we've got him. His multimillion dollar operation in art is going to bust wide open, and some important people, even several governments, are going to be caught in the blast.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's why she was so distant. They had her cornered, but she still tried not to get me involved. As George muses by the window, Sweet paces back and forth

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Remember your neck's on the line, too. You've already told them you saw the real Professor shot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I did. So what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: You be responsible for Hilly. Just get her off the train and to safety. I'll deal with Devereau,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How? Here comes the tunnel. Sweet glances out the window as the entrance to the Rayner Tunnel approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: I'm going to get the conductor to send a coded message to the Bureau. That will be relayed to my chief in Illinois. My guess is we'll make our move when the train gets to Dodge City tonight... Cont.  465 4g 65 Cont.1 A KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Very appropriate. The old ‘Gunsmoke at the Okay Corral.' The train races into the tunnel as Sweet opens the door. Immediately the compartment is plunged into darkness, ani NOISE of the rattling wheels rises sharply in volume. W2 HEAR a gunshot and see a flash. Sweet groans. Gedrge y2ll Another GUNSHOT, another flash, and we HEAR the door clos George turns on the overhead lights as Sweet falls to the floor shot in the chest. ~

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What happened? What the...! He kneels beside Sweet, who is bleeding profusely. Sweet coughs.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Take my gun. Get the girl off, George hesitates. He can see that Sweet is dying...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: (fiercely, despite the pain Take it! George opens his jacket and takes Sweet's gun. Sweet groa and chokes up some blood.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: Leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't... The train comes out of the tunnel, and the noise and dari cease. Sweet looks at George. For a moment he seems to catch his breath. He grins ruefully, clutching his ches+.

dialogues.speaker: SWEET
dialogues.text: You know something? I get the funny feeling this bullet was meant for you. His body suddenly shakes -- and he is dead. George stares him horrified. A KNOCK at the door and Ralston, the porte enters, He steps into the room and looks down at George, ‘Ameeling over the bleeding body with a gun in one hand, the Rembrandt letters in the other. Ralston freaks! Cont.  465 50 65 Cont.2

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Shoot] That man is dead! George stands up to explain, but Ralston looks at the gun his hand and freaks again.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Holy Moley! You shot him!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (advancing) No. No, I...

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: You...you... Ralston backs up, opens the door and races outside,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, GEORGE'S CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Ralston runs down toward the back of the train, alternate yelling and mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: He's been shot! A man's been shot. Sweet Jesus in Bethlehem, a man's been shot! The Mexican Mama-San and the Blue-Haired Lady with the po in the shopping bag are at the end of the corridor, Ralst rushes past them with a hurried warning.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Watch out. He's coming. A man's been shot! George steps out of his compartment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait! Wait! You don't understand. Waving his gun and trying to explain, he advances on the ladies. The poodle BARKS and the women recoil in terror,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN MAMA-SAN
dialogues.text: Santa Maria -- the rapist!

dialogues.speaker: BLUE
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Shrieking like banshees they turn and flee. George stops the end of the corridor and lets them go. The door alongs him opens and Mr, Whiney sticks his head out to see what the fuss is about. He looks at George and is definitely surprised,

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Hey! You're not... (turning inside) Hey! He's not dead. Cont.  465 51 66 Cont. George looks over Whiney's head into the compartment. Gold Teeth is sitting in the chair Cleaning his gun. He, is surprised to see George alive but quickly decides what do about it. Snapping the cartridge into his pistol, he stands up ready to kill. George gulps and bolts down the corridor toward his room, Gold Teeth pushes past Whiney a steps out in the corridor, He sees George and FIRES, The bullet misses and George tears around the corner toward t baggage car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George runs into the baggage car, gasping for breath. He slams the door behind him, locks it, and quickly looks ar for a place to hide. He runs to the other end of the car, stuffing the Rembrandt letters inside his jacket,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth arrives at the baggege car door and tries to o it. It 1s locked. Scowling and grinding his jaws he looks around for a way to break it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes out onto the baggage car platform. He looks a the ladder leading up to the roof and decides that he is afraid to try to escape that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth sees the fire axe on the wall, He smashes the glass with his fist, grabs the axe and begins furiously pounding at the door,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George HEARS the first blow. He comes back into the bagga car and decldes to make a stand there, After all, he has gun so he begins piling up some trunks by the side door a a@ barricade,

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE BAGGAGE CAR ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth is making progress, The lock on the door is beginning to give.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE BAGGAGE CAR
dialogues.text: George kneels down behind the improvised barricade he but and aims his gun at the door. He is ready, He waits, INT, THE BAGGAGE CAR ENTRANCE - DAY Th Gold Teeth continues his furious pounding.  465 52

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE BAGGAGE CAR
dialogues.text: George looks behind him. He puts his gun on a nearby trun and decides it would be a good idea to unlock the side do as an avenue of emergency escape. He opens the latches an tries to pull the door back. He tries again, It opens wit a sudden jerk so unexpectedly that George trips backward knocks his gun off the trunk. He gasps in horror as the g bounces on the floor and tumbles out the open door. He sticks his head out and looks back down the tracks, All h can see is the deep rocky mountain gorge running alongsid the train...certain death to anyone who would try to jump off. The POUNDING at the main door increases and George s the lock is beginning to Give. He closes the side door an faces inside. He looks at his barricade, at the trunks, a the smiling face of the cardboard "Mary-Lou." It is clear he is scared and has no idea which way to turn,

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE BAGGAGE CAR ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth swings the axe furiously, He is like a crazy m singleminded and possessed. At last the lock gives way. Gold Teeth throws down the axe and kicks the door open. Taking out his gun, he advances cautiously,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth steps into the car and drops down behind a tru He looks around. George is nowhere to be seen. He stanis and very carefully begins making his way to the barricada He looks behind it. George is not there, Disgusted, he turns and quickly looks through the rest of the car even pushing over the cardboard cut-out of "Mary-Lou" to see i is hiding behind that. Satisfied that George is not in th car, he walks out onto the baggege car platform. He sees padder leading to the roof. He looks up, smiles, and begi to a. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grade is steep and the train 1s going slow. Very cautiously Gold Teeth pokes his head up and looks down th length of the train. He can't see George anywhere. He stands up on the roof and looks about. Realizing there is way for George to have gone forward toward the engine, he begins carefully walking back toward the rear. As he hops over the canvas covered space between the baggage car and first-class sleeper, we see George's head below him fearfully watching, clinging to the side of the train,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRAIN ROOF
dialogues.text: The train suddenly lurches and George's feet slip. He han in the air, his body banging against the side of the tra: he desperately tries to get a footing before he falls ofs  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: ee

dialogues.speaker: DAY B-78
dialogues.text: Gold Teeth continues walking forward. George regains his footing and climbs back on the roof. Gold Teeth hears him and turns. But George has stood up, slung the underwater spear gun from around his shoulder and is pointing it directly at his pursuer. |

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold it! Don't move or I'1]1 shoot, Gold Teeth looks at the ridiculous spear gun and grins. H evil eyes glint menacingly. He begins slowly to point his gun at George. George fires. In a flash the spear flies through 'the air and imbeds itself in Gold Teeth's should Gold Teeth staggers in shock, lurches over and falls. His body slides off the roof of the train and George watches horrified as it tumbles down the gorge, bouncing from roc to rock till it disappears from sight. George stands on the roof stunned at what he has seen and what he has'done. He looks at the spear gun in his hand and viciously hurls it away. He watches it fall and takes deep breath. Remembering that Hilly is still in danger, h turns to walk back to the ladder. Just then, a low hangin signal arm hits him in the stomach, knocking him off bala and swinging him off the roof. He scrambles and holds on, hanging by his hands till the arm swings him all the way to the hillside. Letting go, he slides on his back down t dirt embankment, stopping by the railroad tracks Just as last car of the train speeds past. George sits up and watches it go with open-mouthed wonder and surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Son-of -a-bitch!

dialogues.speaker: DAY 79
dialogues.text: As the sun goes down in the distance we see George, a lon solitary figure, following the railway lines through the mountains. It is as desolate as the desert.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE MOUNTAINS
dialogues.text: George walks disgustedly along the tracks » throwing ston and muttering to himself. It is getting cold and he turns up his jacket collar. To his right he gees a meadow, a li of trees and the distant mountains. Suddenly above the li of trees he sees a semi-trailer carrying a load of cars. They disappear. George runs down the tracks and through a break in the trees sees a main road. A car passes. Anothe car with its headlights already on speeds by. With a yell of delight George races toward the meadow and scrambles u the bank to the road where because of the frequent traffi it is obvious he will be able to get a lift.  465 REVISED ~ "THE SILVER STREAK" - 4/9/76 5h

dialogues.speaker: EXT, A SMALL MIDWESTERN TOWN
dialogues.text: The main street is deserted as an old truck carrying plum equipment and toilet bowls pulls up in front of the old clapboard Sheriff's office. George gets out and walks acr the dusty street. As he climbs the wooden steps to the Sheriff's office he HEARS A RIFLE SHOT ring out. George jumps. Another RIFLE SHOT and then the SOUND of a fierce battle coming from inside. our 81-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cautiously sticking his head around the corner, George pe through the screen door. OLIVER CHAUNCEY, the town Sheriff is seated back in a cha with his feet up on his desk watching a cops and robbers on television. He is really excited now that the gun batt has broken out.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: That's it, boys. Blow those babies! heads off! George enters and goes up to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, just a minute. Jeezes, would you look at that. Bam! Bam! Bam! Whew! That boy is something, isn't he? Woops! Commercial. He turns down the volume by remote control and swivels ar to face George.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Well, what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I want to report a murder.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A murder. A man's been shot on the Silver Streak. And there's a e@irl -- she's in great danger, We've got to stop the train...

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Hey, hold on a second! you say a man's been shot?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's right. ~ Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Jumpin' Jiminie! We ain't never had a@ murder before. Sit dow. Want a cup of coffee? Help yourself. Okay now, let's get the facts. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Caldwell. George Caldwell. I'm fram Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: (writing L.A. Okay. And who was shot?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Actually there were two.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Two?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. The first was Bob Sweet. He was a federal undercover agent.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: (writing) A Fed! No shit

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And the second was a man named Reace. I shot him.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: You shot him?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. He shot Sweet.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Because Sweet was a Fed?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, because he thought Sweet was me.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: So Reace shot Sweet and you shot Reace?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right. With a spear gun.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: With a what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: See, I took Sweet's gun but I dropped it and had to use a spear gun. Eh, don't you think we could call...

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Wait. You shot Reace with a spear? 465 Cont,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 cont.2

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. He was going to shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: With a spear?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, with a bullet, See, he shot the professor.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Who shot the professor?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Reace,

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Reace shot Sweet,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And the professor.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: And you shot Reace,.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: (looks at his notes) That makes three,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. I forgot. The professor was shot last night. Look, can't we do all this later?

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Was there anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Anyone else what?

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Shot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, but there will be if we don't stop that train. Look, can't you call your superiors? Tell them I have the Rembrandt letters. That's why the professor was shot.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Is he with the Feds?
Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who? 57 84 cont.2

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: This guy Rembrandt.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Rembrandt is dead.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Dead? (looks at his notes) That makes four. (getting angry) Listen, feller, you sure you ain't making this up as you go along? I'm an officer of the law and I got a lot better things to listen to that kind of The phone RINGS. do than funnin',

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: That's my hot line. (stands up) Now you better take the time to get your facts straight 'cause when I come back I want your answers to be clear and to the point. Got that? and you can start with who shot Rembrandt. Chauncey steps into the glass booth alongside his office where the switchboard and dispat closes the door and answers the George takes the train schedule deep groan begins to study it. ch equipment are set up. He phone. Outside a frustrated out of his pocket and with a

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Hello. Yeah, this is Chauncey... No shit...? Jumpin' Jiminie! (softly) He's sitting right here office...That's right! in here spouting a lot about shooting people o Wanted to confess. I k in my He came of bull n the train. new he was a looney right off...0h, yeah. Don't you worry. I've handled looneys vefore. Gotcha! , Chauncey hangs up and looks out through the glass at Gecrge. He reaches for his gun but his holster is empty. He locks Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: , : 84 cont.3 out into the office and sees his gun on the sink. Disgust with himself, he steps out of the booth. George stands up

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Listen, Sheriff, I guess I was a little rattled before...

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Oh, that's quite all right, Mr. Caldwell. That's what you said your name was, didn't you? George Caldwel1?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I really think we ought to get on the phone to Washington. I'm sure if they hear what I've got to say they'll do something about stopping the train. Smiling widely and acting Casual, Chauncey begins to edge himself over to his gun.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah! Well, they're pretty smart, those boys in Washington. You ever watch them on TV? Bam! Bam! Bam! George ignores this. His anger, however, is rapidly risin

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look. They know all about Sweet and Devereau. I figure the Silver Streak will be in Kansas in an hour. We could stop them at Scott City or maybe Dodge. Chauncey grabs the gun off the sink and points it at Geor

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Just keep those hands where they are, mister, and we'll have no trouble. George looks at him. Then at the gun. He is really pissed

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What the...! Give me that. With one quick movement George grabs the gun out of Chaun hand and points it at him. This is so unexpected that Chauncey doesn't believe it happened. Then he throws his hands up in the air.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! Don't shoot! Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 84 Cont.4 George is furious. Waving the gun threateningly at Chaunc he backs him up around the office.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! You stupid, ignorant, son-of-a-bitch, what do you think I'm doing here! Jesus Christ! I've met some dumb bastards in my time but. you outrun them all. Get over there! I come here to get help for @ girl who may be killed any minute and you're running around playing cops and robbers like you're on goddamn television!

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: You ain't never going to get away with this. George stops. He gives up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Aw, to hell with it. Pick up that phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: We know all about you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: That was the county sheriff on the hot line. They're coming to get you. You haven't got a chance.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: To get me? What for?

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: For killing a vitamin salesman on the Silver Streak.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He was no vitamin salesman. I told you. He was a federal agent... They should know that.

dialogues.speaker: CHUANCEY
dialogues.text: Now,. look, things will go a lot easier for you if you just put down that gun and come along quietly. You're outnumbered. There ain't no way you're ever going to escape. Cont.  465 od 84 cont 5) We HEAR a police SIREN and a car approaching,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: That's my deputy. George makes a decision. He picks up his t the Rembrandt letters and motions Chauncey

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Get outside.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: All right. Don't shoot! Don't shoot! You ain't never going to get away with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rain schedule and toward the dcor, 85 The police car drives up as George and Chauncey step out door. MOOSE, the young deputy, calls out happily to the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Hey, Uncle Oliver, guess what I got? George waves his gun at Moose and walks down the steps wi Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Get out of the car, boy.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Uncle Oliver, he's got your gun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: C'mon, get out. Stand over there and keep your hands up. The kid steps out of the car and joins Chauncey standing to the side in the light of the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: The whole county knows about you. They ain't going to rest till they hunt you down. George starts up the engine.

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: Uncle Oliver, he's taking your car George hops in. Cont.  465 61 85 cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: You'ain't never going to get away . with this. .

dialogues.speaker: MOOSE
dialogues.text: But, Uncle Oliver, he's got...

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: One more word out of you, boy, and I gonna smash you in the mouth. The car zooms off in a cloud of dust. As soon as it spins around the corner out of sight, Chauncey drops his hands races up the steps ‘to his office. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey runs around his desk and into the Slass booth. H picks up the phone and quickly presses some buttons.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: J.J. I've got. bad news. Caldwell's escaped...! Look, this ain't no time to go into that. He's headed down three-fifty. We can stop him before he crosses the state line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff's car speeds through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is racing along at sixty miles an hour, mumbling t himself about Chauncey. - a GEORGE Dumb, stupid bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind George's back a pair of handcuffed hands suddenly . appear and grab him by the shoulder. They belong to a y black dude in the backseat by the name of GROVER MULDOONE

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: ‘Hey, man... :

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! George swerves in fright and the black dude is thrown to floor. He pulls himself back up after George straightens the car. .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? .f Cont.  465 62 89 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'ma thief. Now, if I ain't gonna freak you out again, would you mind handing me that set of keys. He points to a set of keys on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. Here. George hands them over and Grover unlocks the handcuffs.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: _ You handled that pretty good back there with old Oliver. I was listening. What they want you for anyway?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Murder,

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: .The big one. Well, maybe you could arop me off at the next corner. I want to thank you but I don't mess with the big time. :

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not stopping anywhere. You know the roads around here? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we can make a deal. I'm no murderer, In fact, I'm trying to stop one. But in a minute we're going to be surrounded by cops. If “you can get us out of it, you'll be doing both of us a favor. Got it? Grover thinks for a moment and makes up his mind.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Make a right up here, then take the first left. I'm coming over. He gets ready to climb into the front seat when George suddenly makes the right turn. Grover tumbles forward and down under the glove compartment. He manages after a few moments of verbal abuse to pull himself together and sit om the seat. He is wearing a flashy blue silk jacket with Oriental dragon emblazoned in gold on the back (along wit the words: When I die I'll go to heaven because I've spen my time in hell. 82nd Airborne Division.") He straightens it out with style. Cont,  465 63 89 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Shit, man! Is that how you murder your victims? Put ‘em in a car and Shake 'em to death.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Sorry? Sorry, my ass. You are one dangerous dude. It proves one thing though. You don't do this for a living.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Well, I'll take over in a minute. Just don't make any more sudden moves while I find out the game plan for tonight. He turns on the police RADIO and tunes into Chauncey's vo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey is in the glass booth sitting at the dispatcher' desk talking into a microphone and studying a map laid ou in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
dialogues.text: He said he was going to get back on that train. That means he's crossing into Kansas on one-twenty, one-sixteen or three-fifty. I figure if we Plot Stakeouts on each of those roads, we can nail that boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauncey's voice continues over the car radio.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: f9-8-) Now, I figure the first should be at the junction of Taubman's Road and one-sixteen...

dialogues.speaker: GR
dialogues.text: Go to it, Oliver... (to George) Hey, killer, what are you slowing down for? cont.  465 64 91 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's a truck ahead...

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: For Chrissake, you're the Man! Let's turn on the sirens and get these weirdos off the road. He leans over and switches on the police red lights and wailing SIRENS. George speeds up. The truck ahead pulls over and George whizzes by. Suddenly a big semi-trailer erosses at the intersection in front of them. Grover yell and springs for the wheel but George sees the danger in t and turns the car, avoiding by inches a certain crash wit the back of the semi. The police car rides off the should of the road, bumps across a field and spins halfway round pefore coming to a dusty halt. George looks over at Grove After a pause he speaks with the calm of a Sunday School teacher addressing a favorite pupil.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You want to drive for awhile? our a-g1- 97

dialogues.speaker: INT, A PATROL CAR
dialogues.text: Two POLICEMEN are driving along to their roadblock point. The Driver is on the radio mike to Chauncey.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Car Thirty-six, Chauncey. We're moving in for a roadblock on the intersection of Taubman's Road and one-sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUNCEY
