dialogues.text: That's fine, fellers. Car Forty-five is already there. We're going for the double block at all points. There ain't no way he's gonna get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grover is listening while he drives.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: The double block, huh? Okay, Oliver, that's all I wanted to know. {turns the radio down and looks over at George) Better buckle yourself in there, killer. What's your name, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: George Caldwell. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 100 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'm Grover T. Muldoone so you ain't got nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I got the nerve and I got the touch. He turns off all the lights in the car including the head lights. George looks concerned as Grover doesn't reduce speed but continues driving by the light of the moon. Gro gestures at George's seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Pull it tighter. That's it. (smiles) No _ sweat, man, I used to do this all the time in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Demolition derby,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: Red flares light up the roadblock and the two police cars parked parallel across the road so that oncoming traffic to slow down almost to a halt to pass between them. Three the policemen are standing by. Then one of them looks up peers into the darkness, grabs radio mike.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: I hear something coming, Chauncey. Can't see anything yet, ur 102- “~~ 103

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE SHERIFF'S CAR
dialogues.text: George sees the red flares and the police cars parked dow the road. They are rapidly coming closer and closer, He turns to Grover. .

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jesus! Aren't you going to slow down?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: (incredulously) . Slow down? You just keep your eyes open, brother. I'm gonna make a criminal of you yet. ! He speeds up and snaps his headlights on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: The Policeman with the mike suddenly sees Grover's car charging out of the darkness toward him, Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 66 105 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Goddamn, fellers! Watch out! He throws away the mike and dives for the roadside. The other Policemen run for safety as Grover, grinning with delight, barrels down toward the roadblock, Spinning the wheel at the last moment, he executes a sliding broadside to the first patrol car that knocks it off the road and i a ditch. The cops hit the dirt. Then, throwing the car in reverse Grover backs up and plows into the other patrol c crashing into it with such split-second timing that, alth his rear bumper is badly bent, the right front bumper of patrol car is buckled around the right front wheel, Both police cars have been knocked out of action and the Polic are nowhere to be seen. Grover laughs. George is in shock Quickly looking around for any sign of pursuit » Grover R ‘forward and with SCREECHING tires, drives off down the r toward the state line. Suddeniy from behind the office, George leaps off the por and does a flying tackle ‘that knocks the Night Watchman the ground. George stands up, quickly kicks away the rifl picks up his gun which has fallen from his belt and shout angrily at Grover. .

dialogues.text: A pussy, huh? Get in the car! Grover is wild-eyed with delight, as he runs around to th driver's seat. . GROVER . Woweeft And I took you for an amateur. It's embarrassin' | He hops in the Porsche and revs up the engine. George scrembies in the other side. With tires SQUEALING they charge out of the lot, turn onto the street and race off into the night. INT. THE PORSCHE - NIGHT i22 Grover is laughing‘excitedly while George is trying to pu himself together. —

dialogues.speaker: / GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I just want...

dialogues.text: You're a bad old dude, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grover is sleeping and George is now driving. He is listening to the song from the radio and thinking about Hilly. Grover opens his eyes and stretches. He looks over at George and sees his deep concentration and furrowed brow.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: You thinking about her? George snaps out of it and looks over at Grover. He attempts a smile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's funny. I just met her last night.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: That's the way it is with love. Fast! I always feel like I swallowed the Fourth of July. George smiles. Grover continues to try to cheer him up.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Don't worry! Like you said, we'll just go in, get her off the train and let the police deal with the rest of it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but...

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I only hope she is still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is six o'clock and the station is beginning to stir wi the first influx of early morning commuters. The Porsche approaches and drives toward the parking lot. 465  465

dialogues.text: George and Grover enter the main door and walk toward the ticket sellers. George looks up at the blg clock.

dialogues.text: Great! We've got ten minutes. I'll get the tickets and... Grover stops him and pulls him back behind some overnight lockers.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: You buy 4 ticket and it's good-bye George.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER

dialogues.text: C'mon. They turn the corner and walk over to a shoeshine stand b the men's room. Grover goes up to the OLD BLACK GUY who runs it, and points at his little transistor.

dialogues.text: Hey, man, I dig that hat. Where'd you get it? I'll give you five dollars for it.

dialogues.speaker: SHOESHINER
dialogues.text: You will? (whips it off his head) It's yours. .

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: (to George) Give him five.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: And another five for his shoe polish.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But what...

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hurry up, man. We ain't got much time. He goes into the men's room. George is very confused. He counts out the rest of the money.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.text: Grover has put the transistor radio and the beanie on the shelf beneath the mirror. He stands at the washbasins wit the open tin of shoe polish and faces an outraged George.

dialogues.text: That is the stupidest idea I have ever heardl 465 Cont.

dialogues.text: 128 Cont.

dialogues.text: Don't believe it. When I was a kid I thought Al Jolson was a brother. Here, you do it. And blot it with this. He gives him another paper towel. George smears on the sh polish while Grover puts his wide, horn-rimmed sunglasses out on the shelf and takes off his jacket.

He may not look like a black man but he ho longer looks like himself. Grover picks up the radio and dials into a hard rock station. He hands Grover's

dialogues.text: Okay, just walk past them with this glued to your ear. Get it. (demonstrates ) Just step 1t out -- like you're king of the Shitkickers' Ball, Kinda cool and easy. Try it. George the transistor and George begins to imitate Jjivey walk. It is a disaster.

Get some jive going, man. George is easing up and getting into the feel of it. He Snaps his fingers as he beps back and forth across the ti floor. Grover puts on George's coat and takes out George' wallet.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Kuh? Cont.  465 75 128 Cont.:

He holds up his hand. Cont.  465 76 130 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER

They climb into the cabin and get ready to mov out.

George has turned off the radio an is seriously looking at the compartment windows as he pas He stops at his old car and looks in Hilly's room. She is not there and her compartment is empty. He looks worried and, gesturing for Grover. to follow, he hops up the step into the train.

Slowly the Silver Str begins to pull out of the station on the last leg of its Journey to Chicago. INT. HILLY'S COMPARTMENT = pay 134 George opens the side door from his room and steps into Hilly's compartment. He looks around. All Hilly's luggage and belongings have been moved. He turns back to Grover.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's gone. He steps back into his room.

dialogues.text: He takes off his beanie and Grover's jacket and suddenly realizes that his room is empty also. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: of course, I'm sure. I guess the police took it all with Sweet's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George goes into the bathroom, sees himself in the mirror and winces. He takes a towel and begins to wipe the shoe polish off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What we've got to do is find out if Hilly is still on the train.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Since you can't leave this room how do we do that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go see if the phony Professor is still in the next car back. Room D. Ask him what happened to his secretary.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Okay, give me the gun. George gives it to him and Grover points it at George.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: And you'd better give me your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Huh? Grover grins, spins the gun in his hand and sticks it in his belt. He is very professional. Cont.  h65

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 136 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'm not going around asking questions without first finding me a porter's uniform. Dig? George picks up his jacket and gives Grover his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: These disguises are getting expensive, .

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: with a smile) I know it, man. Crime costs. He flips George a funny salute and exits. George goes back to the bathroom, turns on the water and washes his face and hands with soap. As he is drying himself off, his eye catches something in the mirror. It is Hilly's cassette tape recorder left up on the upper rack in her room. He goes to look at it, '

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing on her couch, George takes down the tape recorde He fondles it lovingly and presses the button. "HILLY'S THEME" begins to play. He listens to it for a moment end smiles. He starts to go back into his room when Hilly's door opens and she enters. She walks to the window then gasps as she sees George standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George! George runs to her side.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you all right? She 1s about to warn him when a hand with a blackjack (Whiney's) comes down heavily on the back of George's hee He staggers, drops the cassette Player and falls to the f As he siips into unconsciousness the SCREEN BEGINS TO REV like a whirlpool, bringing forth a kaleidoscope of images Hilly's face, the Professor's body, Sweet's murder, Gold Teeth's death, and the Silver Streak itself hurtling down the tracks. "HILLY'S THEME” from the cassette player is gradually replaced by the RATTLING wheels and screamin WHISTLES of the train. All this reaches a climax, then th SCREEN SPINS MADLY, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grover enters hurriedly wearing a red porter's jacket he has managed to rent by bribing a friendly porter.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hey, man. Good news... He looks around at George's empty compartment and sticks head in the doorway of Hilly's to see if George is there. He listens at the bathroom door and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hey, man. Your girl's just moved down the hall. Shets... He stops and opens the bathroom door. George is not there but the water is still running. Grover turns it off and looks around. .

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Where's my man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF SHOTS as the Silver Streak crosses the Mississippi and speeds through the rural countryside of Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is lying on the couch with a wet towel on his head Hilly sits beside him and changes the towel for him. He stirs and opens his eyes. Recognizing Hilly, he begins to get up. He groans and holds his head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you all rignt?

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: That's what I was going to ask you. George smiles ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your head. I never would have gone back for my tape recorder if I'd,.,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My God!... (sits up alert) The Rembrandt letters! Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 140 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Devereau's got them. They found them in your jacket. Where did you find them?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: \ In the cover of the book the Professor gave you for safekeeping. (rubs his forehead) I guess I blew it.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Poor George. I tried not to get | you involved. They came to me | yesterday and told me they had killed the Professor and unless I cooperated they'd kill me too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They've already tried to get me -- twice.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I thought if I went along with them at least you would oo get away. I was really happy when you did... (tears come to her eyes) ---although I thought I'd never see you again. (chokes up) Oh, George. Hold me. She falls into his arms and he holds her tight. She sobs his shoulder for a few moments then he gently takes her r in his hands and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I've been so frightened.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: : So have I. I was scared you wouldn't be here. (brushes away her tears) I missed you, Hilly.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY

A black STEWARD in a white jacket is the breakfast service. Whiney opens the coor George enter.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Come in, come in. (to the Steward) Take this away and bring back some fresh coffee and some more toast for my guests.

dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Caldwell, I've just been looking over the correspondence you brought me. Fascinating! The Professor was correct. It's a remarkable find. I suppose I should have them destroyed but I've always had a soft spot for beautiful things -- particularly if they are genuine. Whiney, put these in my safe. I don't expect they'll be a threat to me anymore. Whiney takes the letters and exits. Devereau removes his reading glasses and puts them away. He is careful to nonchalantly display the gun inside his coat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't be too sure of yourself, Devereau. You're not going to get away with this.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: I think I will, Mr. Caldwell. Admittedly this was a difficult affair and I made some errors <= bringing Reace along, for example. What happened to him, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I shot hin. Cont.  465 82 141 cont.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Good. I'm sure he deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You had him kill the professor, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU '
dialogues.text: On the contrary, I had him kill the professor's secretary --. Miss Burns' predecessor -- when at the last minute she tried to double- cross us, but I knew I couldn't kill the professor himself until I had the Rembrandt letters. That's why I set up the scenario of kidnapping him and substituting an imposter to discredit him. Of course, I would have had him killed later, but his escaping the other night upset the entire scheme...° . A KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Yes. The man who earlier impersonated the professor enters. Hi name is JOHNSON and he is no longer wearing the professor white moustache and goatee, nor is he trying to imitate t professor's manner. He ignores George and Hilly and addresses Devereau.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. It's all been confirmed. The car will be waiting at Joliet.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Thank you, Johnson. (to George) You remember Johnson, Mr. Caldwell. He played the professor and was going to do so in Chicago with the ‘ assistance of Miss Burns but I'm afraid there is no longer any need for that charade. (to Johnson) How long before we get to Joliet?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: About an hour and a half, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Very good, Johnson. That will be all. Cont.  465 83 141 Cont.1 Johnson exits. Devereau smiles affably at George and Hill There is

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Yes, this has been a rather messy pusiness...but now that I have the letters all that remains is the cleaning up of a few loose ends -- meaning the two of you. And-so I've prepared a new scenario in which you, Mr. Caldwell, will be blamed for the murder of the professor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why would I want to kill the professor?

dialogues.speaker: . DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: To steal. the Rembrandt, letters. Even on the black’ market they are worth a considerable sum. At any rate, evidence will'be found on the professor's body implicating you. I've already had that. arranged, Furthermore, since the police want you for the murder of that unfortunate vitamin salesman —- this new evidence. will give you a motive for his death as weil.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAUG
dialogues.text: He found out and tried to blackmail you, so you shot him. Which brings us to the present. ‘In approximately forty-five minutes, the professor's trusty secretary -- gestures to Hilly) -- who is also implicated in her boss! death, quarrels with her lover-partner... (gestures at George) .».and shoots him. He dies but not before shooting her. @ KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Come in. The black Steward in the white jacket enters with the tra cups, plates, toast and fresh coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. Put it down right there. Well, that's enough talk of plots and scenarios, Join me in a cup of coffee. cont.  84 141 cont.2 The Steward lays out the cups on the table in front of Ge and Hilly. George looks over at him and notices for the first time that it is Grover. Grover looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Coffee, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: (to Devereau) But the professor's book will still be published.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Without the letters, my dear, the pook, I assure you, will be viewed as the crazy jottings of a revisionist crank. An ex-crank actually. You must try the marmalade. For all its inconvenience the Silver Streak does provide an excellent cuisine.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. I'll tell the cats in the kitchen. We all aims to please. (to Hilly) Coffee, honey?

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: (reacts) . No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Go ahead, sugar. He ain't bullshitting, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Steward... Grover ignores Devereau and looks over at George.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: She your girl? (winks obscenely) Boogidy-boogidy! She's all right, eh? Patootie-patootie!

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Steward!

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir,
Cont.  465 85 141 Cont.3

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: That will be all.

dialogues.speaker: / GROVER
dialogues.text: Let me pour you some coffee. DEVEREAU . I said that will be all.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Just a short cup. Grover begins pouring the coffee “into Devereau's cup but misses and some splashes into Devereauts lap.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Whoops! Look what I done. ‘Devereau grabs his napkin and begins wiping himself off. is livid. ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it! Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'm awful sorry, sir. Let me help you. Let me wipe that up. Grover takés another napkin and begins brushing down Devereau's suit. Devereau stands up in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: You bDlundering fool! You stupid, ignorant nigger! Grover stops. He throws down his napkin and shoves Devere back in His seat. ,

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hey, that ain't funny, sucker! What you cail me? An ignorant nigger? (whips out his gun) You want to play with me, man? Why you want to mess with me? Are you bad or something? I'1l whip your ass, you mother, I'll whip your ass | Devereau stares with wide-eyed surprise as Grover madly w the pistol in front of his face. George steps over.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, Grover... Cont.  465 86 141 cont.4

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Ignorant nigger! Bullshit! I got a high school diplomal

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, give me the gun. Grover turns to George and sheds his mock anger while han over the gun. .

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: This is the bad ass? Unreal. George laughs and claps Grover on the back. Hilly doesn't understand what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'm a criminal.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay, Hilly. He's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Oh? Hello. Grover smiles at Hilly while George turns to Devereau, ta Devereau's gun from inside his coat and throws it across room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, now, Devereau. Grover goes and sits on the arm of Devereau's chair.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: What's the matter, old dude? You ain't said shit. Devereau pulls himself together and smiles at Grover's jo As he speaks we see his hand move toward the button on th windowsill. He is so riveting and so charming that no one notices him press the button.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: (to Grover) I'll say this. I don't know who you are but I am an internationally respected public figure with a great deal of money and influence. You would be wise to think twice about aligning yourself with a killer who is wanted by the police in every state. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 141 Cont.5

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I forgot to tell you. That vitamin salesman that Reace shot. He was no vitamin salesman. He was a federal agent. They've been trailing you for the last two years, ever since -- what did he. say? -- the plane crash in Cologne linking you with the Metropolitan Gallery scandal..- This information hits Devereau like a bullet. He makes no attempt to conceal it. George gestures for him to stand u He does so calmly but his eyes -- cold like a snake's -- reveal his inner dismay. George opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So let's go get them the proof they've wanted. Let's go get the Rembrandt letters. He waves his gun and Devereau walks out the door. George stays close with the gun poking in Devereau's back. Hilly and Grover follow them out into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George pushes Devereau before him down the corridor. Hill walks behind him while Grover, looking back over his shou makes sure that no one is following them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau and George arrive at the baggage car entrance wh the broken door and smashed lock -- the result of Gold Te assault -- are still unrepaired. George flings open the d pushes Devereau inside and shouts to Whiney who is kneeli in front of Devereau's open safe,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okey, Whiney! Just step away from that. Whiney stands up surprised and puzzled. Move! GEORGE love!

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Do what he says. Whiney steps back. Cont.  465 88 144 cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hilly, go get the letters, Hilly goes over to the safe and begins to look for the letters. Grover joins George alongside Devereau in the middle of the baggage car.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Mr. Caldwell, I take you to be a reasonable man and like all men you must place a reasonable value on your life.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you trying to bribe me?

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: I'm merely pointing out that life is short and the smart man hedges his bets.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I've learned from this trip, Devereau, there's no way to protect your bets, It's play the game and take what you get.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I found themt She stands up with the Rembrandt letters. George smiles a for a second lowers his gun. A SHOT RINGS out and a bulle zips by his ear. Devereau yells out to Whiney and dives f cover behind some crates,

dialogues.speaker: EVEREAU
dialogues.text: Grab the girl] Whiney springs at Hilly, knocks her over and snatches the letters from her hand. Meanwhile, George has turned and fired at Johnson, standing in the doorway. He ducks down fires back. George and Grover hurl themselves over the barrier of trunks and boxes that George had built up earl and flatten themselves on the floor, Whiney, holding Hill as hostage, takes out his gun and begins to fire, George fires back -- first at Johnson on the right then at Whine the left. He fires again and again. Grover panics watchin him fire like he had unlimited ammunition. He grabs his shoulder and shouts madly.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hold it, hold it! How many bullets you got? You think this is a Saturday matinee? We got to get out of here. cont.  465 89 144 Cont. He creeps over and pulls back the side door directly behi them. He looks out toward the front of the train and shou

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Get ready! We're gonna cross a bridge.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: I'm gonna save my ass]

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not jumping! I've left this train twice already... He fires but his gun is empty. Grover sits ready to lead. He shouts at George.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Here it comes. A bullet zaps into the door by George's head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch! He and Grover throw themselves out the side door of the t and fall into the muddy river below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak rattles over the bridge as George and Grover surface. They tread water and watch it go. George muttering and swearing to himself as he and Grover swim t the nearest bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two fugitives pull themselves up on dry land and fall down exhausted. George takes a few deep breaths and begin to shake off the water. He glances at the empty gun still his hand. Grover looks at George for a long moment and finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: What do we do now? Suddenly a calm voice comes down from the ridge.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hold it right there, Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 146 Cont. George and Grover look up beyond the trees and see a high patrol car parked by the side of the road. One of the OFFICERS is standing by his radio mike. The other -- the who spoke -- stands looking down at the two, muddy, wet a dishevelled men with a double-barreled shotgun in his han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is about ready to pull out of the picturesque red-brick station. Johnson, in a public phone booth, finishes up his conversation and hops back on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau is seated by the window calmly burning the Rembr letters page by page into the silver breakfast tray. ‘The train is picking up speed but he doesn't take his eyes of his methodical task. Hilly watches him seated on the couc opposite. Mr. Whiney stands at the door. Devereau says nothing. A KNOCK at the door. Whiney opens it and Johnson steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I talked to Chaney. He'll have the helicopter ready at Rockdale. It's about five minutes from the station. Devereau nods but doesn't bother to look up from the burn letters. Whiney looks at his watch. °

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: We'll be there in forty-six minutes. Devereau nods again. He pokes at the ashes with a fork to make sure that there are no scraps left unburned.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Is there any way of stopping this train between here and there?

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Apart from the engine there's an emergency brake in each car.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Disconnect them.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Okay. All of them? Devereau looks up from the ashes for the first time. Whin gets the message.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: And take her with you. Johnson takes Hilly by the arm and pushes her out the dec Devereau watches him close the door then turns slowly to out the window. He sits and thinks. He is all alone in that large compartment and we see he is beginning to swea  465

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The highway patrol car speeds down a dusty road, with sir wailing and red lights flashing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Grover are seated in the backseat with towels over their heads and blankets wrapped around their wet clothes. The two determined-looking cops in the front are solely intent on getting their passengers to their destin tion as quickly as possible. George leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Couldn't you at least tell us where wetre going?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Shut up. George sighs. The car turns suddenly off to the left and is thrown back on the seat alongside Grover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car careens up to the building and skids to a dusty halt. The police get out and open the back doors. They usher George and Grover up the wooden steps and insi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station has been recently commandeered by the FBI and temporarily converted into a small operations room with telephones, a police radio receiver and a.large map of th area on the wall. Several men with guns strapped in holst under their arms are busily making calls and taking notes The two Policemen bring in George and Grover, and hand ov George's empty gun to a tough, cigar-chewing plainclothes known as the CHIEF. The Chief looks at the gun, ignoring George's angry sputterings.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I demand to know what is happening. Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: You George Caldwell?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: I want some information from you and I want it fast.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't kill Sweet. . Cont.  REVISED - "THE SILVER STREAK" - 4/9/76 ge 152 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: We know that and if you weren't so dumb you would have realized we planted that news story for your own protection. I've had men posted in every station since Dodge City trying to pick you up while you're gallivanting around the countryside wasting valuable time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't know they were ?cderal agents.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Let's see what you do know, Here. (hands over the gun to a surprised George) How many men has Devereau got on the train?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Two,

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: What's his plan after they get to Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They're not going into Chicago. They're getting off at the stop before. At Rockdale. (grimaces I was efraid of that. Okay, Matthews, get onto it. We're going to stop the train before Rockcele... He goes to the map and points out the pian for some of th men.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Closest is the Harris Mill Junction. Contact the railroad. Tell them make out like it's a routine emergency inspection. Have Bronsky bring his men up in choppers from the south and get the passengers off the train. I don't want any shooting. We'll be there as soon aS we can. The men go about carrying out his orders. He turns to Geo and Grover who have both shed their towels and blankets.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Caldwell, you come with us. (to Grover) Steward, what do you want to do? Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 152 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: (very Amos and Andy) Well, boss, I think I'll just go on home. This all been a nerve shatterin' experience for me.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: (to the two Policemen Take him anywhere he wants, boys. C'mon, Caldwell. He throws George a box of shells, takes some for himself exits out the wire screen door followed by the Policemen. George lingers to say good-bye to Grover, who as soon as Chief is gone steals a cigar off his desk. They look in e other's eyes both realizing they have grown very fond of other in their short adventurous relationship and that th will more than likely never see each other again. George looks at the gun in his hand and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's he want me to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Oh, he knows a criminal when he sees one. George laughs. He shakes Grover's hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, thanks. Thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: My pleasure. George doesn't know what more to say. He grins, walks to the door and turns,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If there's anything I can do... Through the wire screen door we see the Chief waiting by car. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caldwell, goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: You better shake it, partner. George nods, opens the door and leaps down the wooden ste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs to the car and hops inside. Grover comes out of t station and waves.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: So long, killer! Keep it loose. George smiles and waves back as the car speeds off down t road. The other cars with wailing sirens follow in a long cloud of dust leaving only the two Policemen standing by their patrol car. Grover takes off the wrapper of the Chief's cigar and walks over to them. One Policeman opens the back door for him. cont.  465 94 153 Cont..

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Where do you want to go to, feller?

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Well, officer... strikes a match on he side of the car) I left my Porsche in Kansas City. He lights the cigar, flips away the match, takes a final at the cars way off down the dusty road, and hops inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entourage of police cars turns off the dusty road and races down the main highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting next to the Chief. He turns to him but the Chief is far too locked up in his own private thought to notice. George looks out the window. our 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak speeds through the countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bald-headed Engineer is driving the train and speakin over the radic intercom to the Conductor in the rear, He has just received the message from the railroad to stop t train at the junction.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: I don't know, Frank. But that's what they said. The Harris Mill Junction.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE TRAIN CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The Conductor is talking into his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll tell my crew.

dialogues.speaker: THE HARRIS MILL JUNCTION
dialogues.text: The two police helicopters land by the old siding. Bronsk and his men get out and speak to the railroad officials a the local police who are already there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue-Haired Lady and the Mexican Mama-San are playing cards by the window. They look up as Ralston enters. Cont.  465 95 158 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ladies. We just got instructions for everyone to evacuate the train up here.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-HAIRED LADY
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PORTER is telling.a group of coach passengers including several hippies that they will have to get off.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I don't know, sir. Some kind of security search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few hardy Conventioneers are listening to a porter teli them they will have to get off the train.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CONVENTIONEER
dialogues.text: That's the damndest thing I've ever heard!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND CONVENTIONEER
dialogues.text: {looking out the window) We're going to stop all right.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD CONVENTIONEER
dialogues.text: There's the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several police cars are parked by the old siding and some plainclothesmen are waiting to board the train. The Silver Streak slows down and comes to a halt. The porters open the doors and the passengers reluctantly begin to get off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Conventioneers, grabbing a few beers to take with the are leaving the car. The porter is helping a very hungcev Plain Jane to maneuver down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Come on, lady. It won't be for long. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162 Cont. Plain Jane stops suddenly and staggers back for "Mary-Lou Putting the cardboard cut-out under her arm, she explains to the porter:

dialogues.speaker: PLAIN JANE
dialogues.text: Us girls got to stick together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since Devereau's window is on the other side of the train does not see the police or the helicopters. He is sitting we left him, deep in his own thoughts, and not seeming to have noticed that the train has stopped. Whiney bursts in He is very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: The police are outside!

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: The porters are asking everyone to get off the train. Devereau leaps up and goes out to the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out the window and sees the passengers streaming off the train and being guided to stand off to the side b the police. One of the Fat Men passes him carrying a large brown pape bag full of groceries. The Conductor walks by.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, Mr. Devereau. We got a call from the police wanting everyone evacuated. Maybe it's @ bomb scare or something.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Well then, we'd better get off.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: I certainly am. The Conductor continues on toward the rear. Devereau drop bis cool manner and walks quickly toward the front. Whine OLLOWS. 465  465 REVISED - "THE SILVER STREAK" - 4/9/76 oT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police entourage drives across the tracks at the rear the train and parks by the abandoned mill. ‘The Chief is first out and walks over to Bronsky. George follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly and Johnson are looking out the window when Deverea and Whiney burst in. Johnson has several rifles laid out the couch. Devereau picks up, one along with several boxe ammunition. Whiney does the same. Devereau loads his rifl with ease, ignoring Hilly while talking to Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Stay here with her and cover us from the window. We're going to start up the engine and take it into Rockdzle. , He finishes loading the rifle when the door opens and Ral steps in. He is surprised to see they haven't left the train.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Hey, you're the last. Everyone's already... (sees the rifles What are you doing with those rifles? Devereau answers by viciously hitting him across the head with his rifle butt. Ralston falls to the floor, unconsci Hilly springs up and goes to his aid, shouting at Deverea

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: You bastard! Devereau. opens the door and exits. Whiney follows. our 167

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief is questioning Bronsky on the evacuation of the passengers.

dialogues.speaker: BRONSKY
dialogues.text: Everyone's off, Chief, except our boy. The Chief looks up and down the train.

dialogues.speaker: -EXT. THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: Devereau steps down off the train followed by Whiney. The begin running toward the engine. The Chief sees them, pul his gun and calls out: Cont.  465 98 169 cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: “Hold it right there, Devereau! Devereau stops and sees the Chief. He recognizes him, aim his rifle and fires. Whiney fires, too. The Chief is not hit but he and the others immediately take cover and retu the fire. George falls to the ground and crawls quickly t safety behind some railway ties. Meanwhile passengers are screaming and running for cover. The Fat Men drop their groceries and hot waddle it to the protection of the mill The Blue-Haired Lady shrieks, her poodle barks and Plain falls flat on "Mary-Lou."

dialogues.speaker: DAY ' A-169
dialogues.text: Devereau and Whiney break away and run for the engine whe they take cover behind a signal box and return the policemen's fire. The police are about to follow when Johnson smashes the train window with his rifle and start firing at them from Hilly's compartment. Caught in the eross fire one of the policemen is hit. The others scramb ‘for new protection.

dialogues.speaker: DAY B-169
dialogues.text: George looks up at the train and catches a glimpse of Hil huddled behind Johnson. Quickly he takes out his gun and begins fumbling to load it with bullets. The noise of the battle crackles around him when suddenly a black pair of hands ENTER THE FRAME and take the gun away from him. Geo turns and is surprised to see Grover crouching behind him

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Hi, killer. What's happenin'? Grover grins and with easy professionalism loads the gun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wha...What are you doing here? A bullet ricochets off the wooden tier and the two men hi the dirt. Grover gets up and peers over the top.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on? Who's in charge here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (grabbing. him) Get down! Grover gets down and finishes loading the gun.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What did you come back for? Cont.  465 99 B-169 cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, yeah...You forgot your wallet. -He hands over the wallet which George accepts with a wry

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Some thief you are.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: (looks up) Hey, isn't that Hilly? George nods. Grover motions for him to follow.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: C'mon. with Grover in the lead the two drop back and begin to ci around toward the rear of the train.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: Meanwhile toward the front of the train the police are be pinned down by Johnson firing from the window and Whiney firing from behind a signal box. Devereau scampers to the locomotive and shouts up at the two drivers.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Start up the engine!

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN
dialogues.text: We can't do that. Devereau shoots and the Fireman falls from the cabin onto tracks. Devereau climbs up into the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE LOCOMOTIVE
dialogues.text: He points his rifle at the Engineer.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Okay, you. Let's get going. The Engineer starts up the engine and the train begins to move, EXT. ‘THE ENGINE - DAY 172 Whiney is crouched behind the signal box, firing at the police. He sees the train beginning to leave and he dashe for the locomotive. A policeman stands up and fires, hitt Whiney in the leg. Whiney grabs for the ladder and is dragged along by the side of the train.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: Se TRE SELVER STREAK" - 4/2/76 EXT. THE REAR OF THE TRAIN - pay 173 George and Grover have circled around and come running up bank toward the departing train. They race to the rear jo and hop on board. .

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE LOCOMOTIVE
dialogues.text: The train is beginning to go faster and Whlney can't hold to the ladder much longer. He cries out for help:

dialogues.speaker: WHINEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Devereaul Mr. Devereaul Devereau looks over the side at hig Wounded comrade. He calculates hig worth, then steps on his hands, Whiney let go with a shuddering Scream and his body rolis orf to the side of the tracks, EXT. THE JUNCTION - pay 175 The Chief stands up and sees the train getting away. He . calls out to two of his riflemen to follow him and rung b toward the helicopters, He shouts out to Bronsky to get i one of the choppers while he and his riflemen get into th er, INT. THE LOCOMOTIVE - pay A-175

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE COACH LOUNGE
dialogues.text: George follows Grover as they run through the empty loung where the conventioneers held their two-day party,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE JUNCTION
dialogues.text: The two police helicopters take off and follow the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is racing along the rails at full speed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly has put a bandage around Ralston's head, but he is still very groggy. Johnson takes his rifle and the rest o the ammunition and pulls Hilly up off the floor. Cont.  265 icl 179 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: . JOHNSON
dialogues.text: We're getting off at the next stop. He pushes her out the door and they walk back down the corridor toward the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Grover run down the corridor past the Professo old room toward the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau leoks back and sees the police helicopters flyin alongside the train. He ducks for cover and takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson enters with Hilly and looks out the windows. He s the helicopters and roughly throws Hilly down at one of t tables. Taking his rifle butt, he smashes the train windo

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The helicopters are flying alongside the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau pops up and fires several rounds at them. The helicopters fly away. INT. THE CHIEF'S HELICOPTER - DAY c-182 The Chief gives directions to one of his sharpshooters.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Take another pass. Watch out for the engineer but get me Devereaul

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The two helicopters fly by the locomotive. They open fire Devereau ducks then fires back, our 182

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE LOCOMOTIVE
dialogues.text: The Engineer watches Devereau concentrating on beating of chopper attack and so very slowly he takes his foot off t pedal. Devereau turns round and sees the Engineer's foot move. He snaris. Cont.  465 lo2 183 cont.

dialogues.speaker: DEVEREAU
dialogues.text: Keep your foot on that pedal! The Engineer quickly puts his foot back and wipes his bro with his handkerchier, »

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson has finished Clearing the glass from the window. kneels down and takes aim.on the second helicopter. Just then Grover runs through the door. Before he sees Johnson Johnson sees him and, swinging around quickly, fires. Gro crashes into some tables and tumbles to the floor while h gun slides out into the aisle. Hilly screams. George ente and dives for the gun.. Johnson sees him and stands to fi Hilly picks up a chair and smashes Johnson in the chest w it. He turns to knock her with his rifle when George pick up the gun and fires. Johnson staggers back with a bullet hole in his, chest. He falls, grabs at a tablecloth and r under the table, dead. George runs to Hilly and she holds him tightly. after a moment he looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You all right? -

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I'm fine. How about Grover? They walk back to the pile of broken dishes, silverware a debris where Grover fell. George lifts up the tablecloth a stunned Grover staggers to his feet while tenderly feel his lips.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: ‘Holy shit! I chipped my tooth!

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak as it approaches Joliet is leaving behi the tree-studded countryside and is speeding past small factories’ and town dumps. Above the locomotive the rifle in the helicopters trade gunfire with Devereau who sudden makes a good shot and wounds Bronsky in the second choppe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bronsky slams against the Pilot forcing the helicopter in @ sudden spin, EXT, THE TRACKS - DAY c-184 We see the helicopter tallspinning. Various CUTS as it ge closer to a certain crash with the train.  465. REVISED ~ "THE SILVER STREAK" - N/e/ 76 103

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Hilly and Grover look out the window and see the helicopter flying straight at them. They all quickly take cover and drop to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter pulls out of the spin and flies over the train. INT, THE LOCOMOTIVE - DAY — A-185 The Engineer sees Devereau following the helicopter and surreptitiously takes his foot off the pedal. Devereau doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief looks over and sees the other chopper.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Bronsky's been hit. Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: RIFLEMAN
dialogues.text: Just give me one more pass. The Chief nods okay and the Pilot swings around again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the SOUND of gunfire George races to the broken window and looks out toward the engine. Hilly and Grover crowd behind him. George sees Devereau leaning out of the engin ready to fire at the helicopter. He turns back inside.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Gimme that rifle. I've got an idea. He picks up Johnson's rifle and leans out the window. our 188- ~— 190 INT. THE LOCOMOTIVE - Day 191 The Chief's helicopter readies for the attack. Devereau i firing madiy. Suddenly a buzzer sounds and the train begi to lurch. Devereau looks around at the Engineer and sees that the Engineer's foot is off the pedal. The train is about to stop. The Engineer panics and backs aw. - Devere fires, killing him dead. His body falls from the train. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: ——— ee en ef 191 Cont. Devereau dives for the Pedal, pressing it down with his f The warning buzzer goes off. The danger is over. Devereau crawls to a heavy toolbox, drags it back and places it on the pedal so that it will always be pressed down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pilot flies toward the engine. The Rifleman aims his rifle. :

dialogues.speaker: RIFLEMAN
dialogues.text: Just give me one clear shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau, finished with his work, grabs his rifle and lea out of the cab to shoot. From the first-class diner windo George fires. The bullet misses but Devereau turns around exposing himself to the helicopter flying overhead. A bul hits him in the shoulder. He spins around by the cabin door and begins mad and reckless firing at the helicopter Another bullet hits him in the knee. He trips and tumbles out of the engine, dropping his rifle and desperately hanging on to the ladder with one hand. His other hand swings for the steps and he grabs them. He looks ahead an we ZOOM in on his terrified face as he sees what is approaching. .  465 104

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freight train, travelling on the tracks alongside the Silver Streak is careening toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devereau's face fills with fear. He frantically tries to crawl back into the cabin but the speeding freight trair. rushes past, knocking him off the ladder and hurling hir up into the air. His body bounces between the two trains, then falls beneath the Silver Streak's rattling wheels. A train whistle SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief and the Rifleman wince at Devereau's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George too has seen Devereau's death. He pulls his head inside the window and the freight train rattles by. Hilly leans forward to see what happened but George stops her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't look...They got Devereau. The freight train passes and George turns back to the window. He sticks his head out and waves at the Chief's chopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chopper is flying alongside the Silver Streak. ‘The Rifleman gestures to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: RIFLEMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Chief! There are still people on that train.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: It's Caldwell. In a flash the Chief recognizes the danger. He turns to the Pilot,

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Get back to the junction. Call ahead and tell them they've got @ runaway train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grover has his head at another window, Cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-198 cont.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: There goes the choppers. And here comes the station.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Thank God it's over! George looks out the window as they approach Joliet. His face shows a mounting concern. :

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak speeds past the flashing telephone pole and right through the station of Rockdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Hilly are seated together by the window watchi the station whiz by. She turns to him very troubled.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Why didn't we stop? George stands up. He is pale and beginning to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: George, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure yet, but it looks like there is no one up front in the engine.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: No driver?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: My God! What are we going to do? George looks over at the emergency brake in the corner of dining car. He races over and pulls it. ‘The cord comes o in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What the...!

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: (a gasp of horror) Devereau ordered Whiney to disconnect them, He cut every one of them throughout the whole train. 465 Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 200 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Terrific!...Then I've got to get to the engine.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: How? George looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: The roof? George mutters an agreeing oath.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak speeds out of the city limits and into countryside, zipping past lush meadows, lakes and marshes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JERRY JARVIS, @ young man with a supercilious manner, is speaking on the phone to the radio OPERATOR at the juncti He 1s the assistant controller and is explaining the abso impossibility of the Silver Streak being a runaway.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Nonsense! The engineer is probably anxious to bring the train in on schedule.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: The engineer is dead.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Look, if the engineer takes his foot off the pedal for twenty seconds the entire train goes into emergency stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief's helicopter lands and the Chief runs over to t police van where the Operator is talking on the radio pho How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: They don't believe us. The Chief grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: This is Chief po: . Who's this? "on#tdson our 204  465 107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: This is Jerry Jarvis. I'm the assistant controller.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Assistant? Get me your boss.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: He's out to lunch but I'm sure I can handle any problem you might have.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: It's not my problem. You've got a dead engineer and a runaway train that's going to hit Chicago in twenty-five minutes. Now what are you going to do about it?

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: All right, I'll check with the signal towers. But, you see it's impossible. If the engineer is dead, who's driving the train?

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE LOCOMOTIVE
dialogues.text: The toolbox is still pressed down on the pedal. From the cabin we see the countryside is giving way to industry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sliver Streak speeds by and a man in a signal tower i surprised to see no one at the controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Hilly and Grover are moving down the corridor whe the door opens and Ralston steps out. He has the bandage around his head and is feeling a little woozy.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Are you all right? Ralston looks up, sees George and staggers back.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Holy Moly! It's the killer! Cont.  465 108 208 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: No, no, He's all right. Listen, is there any way to gét to the engine without going over the roof?

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: There's no way to get to the engine period. Why do you want to... (looking out the window) What's the matter? Why are we going 80 fast?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's no one driving the train.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: That's impossible. It would stop.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Does this look like we're stopping? Ralston gets the message. He goes over to the emergency c in the corner and pulis. It comes out in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Those damn hippies!

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak zooms past a large gravel quarry and a network of power lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A now very nervous Jarvis is back on the phone talking to Chief.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: I received a report fram the signal towers. They see no engineer in — the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Great! Now you've got the facts why don't you just throw one of those switches and have the train run off on a siding,

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: That's the problem. All the tracks are computer programmed. Switching the Silver Streak would only cause a collision with another train. cont ont.  109 211 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Then what the hell are you going to do? There are people riding on that train!

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Oh, not (sweating profusely) You see, the standard procedure in such an emergency would be to derail the train,

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Derail it! In the middle of the yard?

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Actually, I can't take that responsibility myself. I'd better get my boss.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: You better do something, you idiot. Because in ten minutes you're going to have two hundred tons of locamotive smashing through Central Station on its way to Marshall Fields! The Chief angrily hangs up the phone. He turns to the rad Operator.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: They can't stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is speeding along the rails, changing a the switches and scooting past an automobile graveyard fu of a long line of smashed and broken cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilly looks out the window and turns to George.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The only thing we can -- insulate ourselves against one mighty crash.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Come on. (insistently) Come on! Everybody follow me. Somewhat bewildered they follow him down the corridor.  465 REVISED - "THE SILVER STREAK" - 479/76 llo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak has reached the outskirts of Chicago, a already it is racing alongside the cars on the freeways t lead into the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the vast space of the grand concourse we see Jarvis ru down the marble steps and cross the open floor. He races under the arch that says "To All Trains," passing the ste lockers, the wooden benches and the new Dodge Dart draped with red, white and blue bunting that is on display. He s a RAILROAD OFFICIAL and rushes up to hin.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack, where's Benny?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He was in the coffee shop... Jarvis races away much to Jack's bewilderment. our 216

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: With wheels spinning and its red lights flashing, the Silver Streak enters the vastness of the Chicago railway yard. our 218

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralston steps out on the platform and points out to the others the steel floor that connects the two cars,

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Lift it up. George and Grover lift up the floor and we can see the connecting bolts and hoses that keep the cars together. W can also see the railway bed zipping by underneath. Ralst points out his plan.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: What we're gonna do is uncouple the cars 'cause when they pull apart they will bust open the air pressure lines and the brakes will clamp on throughout the train,

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: That's brilliant! cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 219 Cont. HILLY (Cont. ) (looks at the speeding wheels beneath them) But -- that's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do we have to do?

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: You see that pin. dow there? You've got to pull it up and turn it to the left. George and Grover bend down and look.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: That's impossible!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to Greve) C'mon. You hold the back of my belt. George eases himself toward the pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak tears along the tracks over bridges and freeways. In the distance we can see the skyline of Chica

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarvis, anxious’ and sweating, races into the coffee shop looks around frantically for Benny, then races up to the cashier.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Mabel. Have you seen Benny?

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly) Well, if it isn't the little caesar of the railroads. What's... Jarvis leans over the counter and grabs her lapels.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: Have you seen Benny?!!

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: No. No. Try next door, Jarvis lets her go and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying flat on his belly George slides himself down toward bolt. Grover and Hilly are holding him while he looks at Cont.  465 112 222 Cont. speeding railway tracks below. He finds a place for his h and inches his way toward the pin. He gets his hand on it and tries to move it. It won't budge. George wipes the sweat from his face and mutters an oath,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is flying by signal towers and along th mazes of crisscrossing tracks. INT, THE CONNECTING PLATFORM - DAY 22h George tries again without success. He has to move closer for more leverage. Grover leans over holding him by the belt, while Hilly holds his leg. George gets his hand on the pin again and gives it a mighty pull. It moves.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I moved it! Suddenly the train lurches and Grover loses his grip. Geo tumbles down, scrambling madly for balance. Hilly screams He stops himself in time, his face not more than two feet from the gravel railway bed. Hilly grabs at his clothes a Grover takes hold of his legs. Together they manage to pu him back to his original position. George takes a few dee breaths and tries again to move_the pin.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE BRASS RAIL
dialogues.text: Jarvis runs into the crowded bar and races over to BENNY is having a beer with some friends. He grabs his boss and pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: JARVIS
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is a runaway. What do we do? Benny, a professional railroad man for many years, sees i lately from Jarvis' manner that the problem is serious. H looks up at the clock above the bar. It reads one thirty-

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: It's gonna be here in four minutes. He slams down his beer and races out of the bar. Jarvis follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benny and Jarvis run from the bar, past the center newsst the Kodak camera booth, and the record stall. They race u the ramp where the Dodge Dart is on display and over to a security phone set in the wall. Benny takes it out and di one number. - Cont.  465 113 226 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: BENNY
dialogues.text: Harris? Benny. Get a call into station security. The Silver Streak is going to jump track five and crash in here in four minutes. Full alert. Clear the station. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak is hurtling toward the downtown area. W can see the tall buildings, including the Sears building, tallest in the world, and for the first time we glimpse Central Station waiting at the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George makes another attempt at the pin. He moves it and pulls it up but he hasn't got the strength or the leverag turn it to the left. He sweats and grunts. Hilly looks at him with an anguished face. Grover, holding onto George's belt, watches the tracks zipping by. He too is sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public address system echoes across the vast marble concourse. People stop -~ passengers, waiting relatives, waitresses, newspaper sellers -- and listen.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLIC ADDRESS
dialogues.text: Attention. You attention please. Everyone is requested to walk to the nearest exit as quickly as possible. This is an emergency. People waiting for the arrival of the Silver Streak on track five are requested to vacate that area immediately. Repeat. This is an emergency... People mill around and talk amongst themselves. Some are going to the exits. Others are asking the security police for more information.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The Sliver Streak is shooting past the other trains in th yard and headed directly for Central Station, built under large post office in the middle of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are moving a little more quickly toward the exits the security police hurry them along and shout out instru tions. Coffee waitresses are refusing to leave the shop a the man at the newspaper stand does not want to leave his stall. Old people scurry along as fast as they can while young kids giggle and yell and take their time.  465 114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak never looking more powerful is barrelli down the tracks -- sleek and smooth and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE CONNECTING PLATFORM
dialogues.text: George maneuvers himself closer to the pin. He looks down the speeding tracks and gathers his strength for one last effort. The muscles of his face are pulsating. The veins his neck stand out. All his body shivers with the strain when suddenly the pin turns free. The train lurches and t cars pull apart. The hoses break, and, like a banshee wailing, the air pressure escapes and the brakes come on. Sparks fly fram the wheels, and piercing SCREECHES fili t air, as the wheels lock and slide along the track. George scrambles back up with the aid of Hilly and Grover. Grabb onto the end of the car, they watch the forward section o the train draw away and speed on without them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRACKS
dialogues.text: The powerful locomotives of the Silver Streak are not deterred by the brakes. The forward section of the train races ahead into Central Station and disappears from sigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the windowless darkness, past the black asphalt siding piled high with baggage and mail sacks, the Silver Streak roars down the tracks toward the heavy wooden stop at the of the line.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 236
dialogues.text: A few last stragglers are being ushered away from the ccn crete block wall at the back of track five. A security of cer is arguing with a woman and her children when suddenl her littlest boy playfully rus out into the empty waiting area. .

dialogues.speaker: INT, CENTRAL STATION
dialogues.text: The Silver Streak with the power of a rocket careens down tracks and smashes into the wooden stop, shattering it li kindling. The locomotive continues on, grinding up and ov the embankment toward the concrete brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 238
dialogues.text: On the other side of the wall, the security officer dives grabs the little boy, rolling to safety as the Sliver Str smashes through. The concrete bricks fall and tumble like children's blocks and still the train keeps going. People scream, The newspaperman leaps out of the way as the migh engine plows through his stall, crashes through the recor poutique and completely demolishes the glass Kodak booth. Cont.  465

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 238 Cont. And still it keeps going. Up the ramp, past the Greek mar pillars, through the display and smack into the new Dodge Dart sending it flying through the air like an angry bull tossing a matador. The car smashes into the wooden benche and the Silver Streak finally slows to a SCREECHING halt beneath the arch that says "To All Trains."

dialogues.speaker: INT, TRACK FIVE
dialogues.text: The rear of the train slides to a halt at the platform no more than thirty yards from the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE CAR WITH THE CONNECTING PLATFORM
dialogues.text: As the train stops, Grover, whe has been looking out the corridor window, leans back against the wall with incredu relief,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made it. I don't believe it. We made it. Ralston, who is sitting in the far corner, takes out his hip flask and toasts the opening at the end of the car.

dialogues.speaker: RALSTON
dialogues.text: Hello, Chicago, hello! He takes a long swallow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George steps off the carriage and plants his feet firmly the ground. He draws a long breath and then turns to help Hilly down, She falls into his arms and they hold each ot for a moment of great relief and happiness. Grover steps and glances up toward the end of the track.

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: Wow! Would you look at that! George and Hilly look up and the three of them walk off t the end of the platform. -

dialogues.speaker: DAY C-239
dialogues.text: They pause at the end of the line to look with wide-eyed amazement at the hole in the concrete wall that the Silve Streak left when it crashed through. They step through th hole and walk through the destroyed boutique. our 24o  465

dialogues.speaker: DAY 241
dialogues.text: People and security officers are milling around, recoveri from the shock. George, Hilly and Grover make ‘their way across the floor scattered with candies and magazines fro the wrecked newspaper stall. They pass what is left of th record shop and the Kodak booth and see the last carriage the Sliver Streak up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: It's like a battlefield. They walk on. :

dialogues.speaker: GROVER
dialogues.text: (pointing) Look what it did to that car. INT. CENTRAL STATION - ANOTHER ANGLE ~- DAY aka The Silver Streak locomotive has taken a beating, althoug the whole front of the engine is incongruously draped wit the festive red, white and blue bunting from the Dodge Ca display. George and Hilly stand off and look at it.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: I don't know about you but next time I take the bus.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know I look at the face of that engine and I swear I can see @ grin.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Looks to me like one of those Bicentennial displays.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where's Grover? They look around and see Grover over by the Dodge Dart wi his hands in the engine.

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think he's just bagged himself another pussey. Grover slams down the Dodge Dart hood and, officiously ordering people to get out of the way, sits at the wheel begins to slowly drive orf through the crowd. He passes George and Hilly and winks before he dissappears down a r George shakes his head and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He's crazy!

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Crazy? Hets got the right idea. Let's get out of here. Let's go to a park.  465

dialogues.speaker: SED
dialogues.text: 242 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A park?

dialogues.speaker: HILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want to take my shoes off, lie back on the grass and have you teach me some more about gardening, George laughs and takes her in his arms. They kiss. The MUSIC comes in and we begin PULLING BACK, High above the crowd we take our last fond look at the Silver Streak. Parked in the middie of Central Station the focus of attention, it still seems to be flashing a wickedly satisfied grin. our 243
